text: what I'm showing you here again the coverage strangle in this context is designed for something that you would want to hold anyways now the way that I trade it when it's moving around a lot I'll use single options and trade the actual Direction the purpose of this strategy is to optimize an existing holding position of stock so the base position in the coverage triangle is long shares and then the options are just to amplify the position GameStop presents a really interesting opportunity because it's very very high volatility and the options positions that we use in this strategy are both short options positions so it means we're selling we're selling options in something that has very high volatility that means that you're going to make a lot more money on a relative basis compared to selling options on something with lower volatility you're also taking advantage of some structural components of volatility things like volatility risk premium vrp now that sounds a little heavy but it's a very simple concept if we take a look at this chart of GameStop you you'll notice this is volatility this yellow line is implied volatility for a 30-day time frame this gray line is one month Vault it's 21 days technically but it's also one month Vol so both yellow and gray are one month volatility notice how in general implied volatility is higher than realized volatility in general when you sell options you capture some of this depending

text: frame this gray line is one month Vault it's 21 days technically but it's also one month Vol so both yellow and gray are one month volatility notice how in general implied volatility is higher than realized volatility in general when you sell options you capture some of this depending on how you structure the trade and manage it but in general when you're selling options if implied volatility remains elevated it means that you are collecting more premium than the underlying is actually moving so there's an edge baked into this from the options perspective which is why something like GameStop is so advantageous it has 110 IV that's for a 30-day time frame the implied volatility percentile is 53 so it's very very high volatility and for comparison if this doesn't make a lot of sense to you let's take a look at Apple AAPL Apple has 26.6 Vault this is a 68 implied volatility percentile implied volatility percentile is a really simple metric that plots all of the previous for the last year implied volatility numbers against the current implied volatility and this simply tells you that the current level of V is higher than 68 of the time mean it's very high so then if we go to GameStop by comparison it's almost quadruple plus the volatility from on average right now V is actually a little bit low in here but it's 110 V compared to 25 V and notice how implied volatility percentile is

text: at some point but you want to own the stock anyways and this isn't like The Superficial people that sell a put and they collect the premium and they say oh I want to buy the stock anyways and then the stock plummets and they're like wait a minute I don't actually want the stock it's I'm beyond that I've thought through that enough I've seen enough of these cycles that when I'm selling these puts at spots that I actually would want to be assigned I'm selling them pretty aggressively closer to at the money so that's why it's something that you want to hold anyways the difference is let's say we're using a 115,000 position rather than going into the long shares in just buying all 115,000 worth we maybe do a little bit less maybe 10,000 Worth or less than that and then get the rest via those short puts so that you can capture some of that premium particularly when the underlying is doing stuff like this kind of trending sideways or even coming down a little bit so let's talk about the management plan the risk in my GameStop coverage triangle is defined by its size the allocation that means that I would be completely okay and comfortable if GameStop went to zero meaning my entire investment is lost that's not the standard for most of what I trade most of what I trade is way more actively managed with stops and things like that

text: size the allocation that means that I would be completely okay and comfortable if GameStop went to zero meaning my entire investment is lost that's not the standard for most of what I trade most of what I trade is way more actively managed with stops and things like that but I'm using my allocation as my risk management approach and that is because I know GameStop can go through prolonged periods where it kind of just Trends sideways goes down a little bit and those can actually be really great accumulation phases so my risk risk is defined by the allocation again not my normal but when I'm trading the coverage strangle that's generally the case now if I'm trading the cover strangle on something like a leveraged ETF I normally apply some sort of trend following different scenario so that's the risk management perspective now I do not intend to unwind the shares unless we're in the process of a squeeze and I would Define that as any sort of movement similar to this where we're seeing volume jacking we're seeing price double triple Plus at least doubling so that means from current steady state right now I wouldn't unwind any shares until it is at least above 50 probably closer to 60 and the share unwind in that instance is not to get out of the stock it's to realize a profit to make more money to then sell more puts and buy more stock that's the

text: wouldn't unwind any shares until it is at least above 50 probably closer to 60 and the share unwind in that instance is not to get out of the stock it's to realize a profit to make more money to then sell more puts and buy more stock that's the Bey of the strategy so it's opportunistic upside unwinds to realize the gain so that I can then use the money to buy more when it comes down because as we know from squeezes they're shortterm they don't last forever they actually typically last fairly briefly so what I'm doing is I'm setting targets based on double current price so double current price starts to open unwind potential for the shares so so that's the upside now the next management component is how I'm how am I deciding between selling puts versus buying shares and it's by Price Direction and standard analysis if I see price doing what it's doing now trending sideways this period in here is via short puts then if we had a period like this where it's more aggressively Rising I would take some of the short puts in and buy the shares outright because I will make more money on the move as it goes so the goal for the strategy is to remain pretty much always at least 70 invested if not more and depending on what the stock is doing it will e and flow how much of that is going to be
